Diploid cells, somatic cells, contain 46 chromosomes, with 23 pairs-one from each parent. Haploid cells contain only 23 chromosomes and are missing half of what diploid cells possess. If I am wrong, please do not hesitate to correct me!

For those curious, it is now understood how the kinetochore microtubules "pull" the sister chromatids: the kinetochores depolymerize the microtubules, which results in the breakdown of the microtubule into tubulin subunits. This effectively shrinks the microtubule, resulting in the chromatids moving towards the centrosome.

The centromere is the point at which the chromatids are joined (the middle of the X, pretty much). Kinetochores are small proteins that are near the centromere and attach the chromosome to the microtubules, which come out from the centrosomes (the things at the poles of the cell) and pull the chromosomes into position.

In the cell cycle there are different phases G1, S, G2, and M.
S-phase is where the DNA is replicated
in G2 phase the cell creates more organelles not through replication, only certain organelles replicate themselves (mitochondria and chloroplasts) because they contain their own set of DNA.

Note that he uses the X-shape of chromosomes even in S phase. That is to achieve simplicity. Such shapes do not appear until metaphase. By prophase the cohesion between the sister chromatids starts to dissolve from the chromosomal arms but not yet from the centromeres. Centromeric cohesins are lost only in anaphase, that finally sets the sister chromatids apart.

Actually, the chromatin is what the chromosomes are made of. Chromatin is the ordered assembly of the DNA with the histone proteins into the nucleosomal structure. When the chromatin is in its relaxed, spooled-out shape, it is called popularly "chromatin network". Distinct, identifiable chromosomal shapes start to apear only in prophase, when the chromatin condenses.  So, chromatin is the same as chromosome, just as a gene is a region of DNA!

damn,this guys really good but im so bummed because biology is now boring to me when ive been studying it or trying to do so and learn over 3 years of work in a little over a month

@NLx360 Each daughter gets at least one of each organelle.  If there was only one of a given organelle prior to mitosis, it is divided between the two daughters. How each daughter get along with only only part of an organelle, is that the DNA in each of the cells has all of the information necessary to construct any organelles that the cell needs.  Thus, the cells can build more of each organelle, and they can also complete any partial organelles that they have.
It makes sense now!

@NLx360  Organelles that exclude chloroplasts and mitochondria are "divided" into the two cell.  It is done unequally  however but it doesn't matter because the cell has the directions to produce more organelles.  Chloroplast and mitochondria however replicate on their own indipendent of this process because they have their own DNA

@bessyakabossy Totally agree!

@Aleksi535 Most teachers teach that non-disjunction only takes place during meiosis, but it can also occur during mitosis (aka post-zygotic non-disjunction)... The resulting cells are not sister cells (twins) due differences in the number of chromosomes. This leads to mosaicism. A small portion of individuals in the Down syndrome (trisomy-21) population are actually mosaic. Their condition is said to be "de novo," which means afresh in Latin. My thesis was on trisomy-21 for UD genetics.

@ominousy I suppose so, but I think remembering the entire phrase of "I Pull Me A Twin" is the key; it was thought out that way to associate the name with the process of producing to sister cells (twins) and help on exams to remember the sequence of the different phases... It helps with a number of things... that is, they are only twins if everything goes as planned =) if genetic mutations, such as non-disjunctions, take place, then the cells won't be twins and yeah (different N numbers)...

@Aleksi535

An easy why to remember the name of the stages is the acronym IPMAT, which stands for, "I Pull Me A Twin." And it actually makes sense... to a certain extent (Interphase, Prophase, Metaphase, Anaphase and finally Telophase). Hopes this helps! Aleksi.
There is also a G0 phase, Sal. During G1, there come time to prepare for S phase, so technically it's not the growth phase. G0 is the actual growth phase.
